prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors articulated by the Panel in selecting transferee district—Nature of pending actions

para.paratext: In addition to looking at the number of actions pending in various districts, the Panel will sometimes look at the nature of the actions. One example of this exists in the case of multiple class actions. This situation makes transfer likely.[1] Where the class actions are different in scope, the Panel may quite logically prefer transfer to the district where the broader action is pending.[2] The Panel has also transferred cases to a district where related MDL proceedings are pending.[3] The Panel may also look at the breadth of the claims asserted in several actions, and select as the transferee district the court having the most comprehensive case or cases.[4]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See, e.g., In re: Fluidmaster, Inc., 65 F. Supp. 3d 1397 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014) (broadest complaint in action pending in the chosen transferee district); In re Oreck Corporation Halo Vacuum Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 842 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Novartis Wage and Hour Litigation, 460 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (action broader in scope pending in transferee district); In re Pineapple Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (action in transferee district includes both direct-and indirect-purchaser claims); In re Wireless Telephone Services Antitrust Litigation, 249 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
See, e.g., In re Laughlin Products, Inc., Patent Litigation, 313 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2004).

See, e.g., In re Suboxone (Buprenorphine Hydrochloride and Naloxone) Antitrust Litigation, 949 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2013) (transfer to district where both direct- and indirect-purchaser claims pending); In re Loestrin 24 Fe Antitrust Litigation, 2013 WL 5505369 (J.P.M.L. 2013) (same); In re NeuroGrafix ('360) Patent Litigation, 936 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2013); In re Frito-Lay North America, Inc. All Natural Litigation, 908 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2012) (action in transferee district encompasses all claims in litigation); In re Federal Nat. Mortg. Ass'n Securities Derivative & “ERISA” Litigation, 370 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
